content.question: Two transmitters in space emit electromagnetic waves with frequencies that differ by <math alttext="1 Megahertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>M</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>z</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. How do the wavelengths of the waves compare?

choices.label: The waves have the same wavelength because all electromagnetic waves travel at the speed of light.
The wave with the higher frequency has the longer wavelength.
The wave with the higher frequency has the shorter wavelength.
The wavelengths cannot be compared unless the specific frequencies of the waves are known.

content.answer: The wave with the higher frequency has the shorter wavelength.
